newsitem.title: UK: Dollar boosts Eurobourses, gold slides.
newsitem.headline: Dollar boosts Eurobourses, gold slides.

text.p: The dollar surged to a near two-year high against the mark on Tuesday, powering German shares to yet another record and the Paris bourse to its highest levels this year.

British stocks also overcame some of their interest rate jitters to recoup Monday's fall on the back of a strong bond market and Wall Street's overnight rebound from a near 50-point deficit to a flat close.
Gold hit its lowest level in three years, being fixed at $369.00 an ounce. It was off its overnight lows but traders forecast it could go even lower with mining companies desperate to sell.
The dollar steadied just below its 23-month highs in Europe after making impressive gains overnight on comments from two central bank officials.
Foreign exchange markets were galvanised by Bundesbank chief economist Otmar Issing saying investors might want to switch into dollars in the runup to Europe's economic and monetary union (EMU).
New York Federal Reserve Bank President William McDonough said he believed the dollar might become more important as a reserve currency in the runup to EMU in 1999.
"The dollar's status as a reserve currency has dwindled in the last 15 years...But that has halted ahead of EMU," Gerard Lyons, chief economist at DKB International, said.
The mark's softness against both the dollar and yen will please the French. They have argued for a dollar rise against the mark which would feed through into a more competitive franc.
"The Bundesbank wants a weaker deutschemark. They need a weaker deutschemark," Lyons said.
By 1015 GMT the dollar was quoted at 1.5653 marks and 114.07 yen against 1.5428 marks and 113.68 yen in late Europe on Monday.
On European stock markets, Germany's 30-share DAX index stormed to a fresh record at the opening on the rise of the dollar which makes German exports more competitive.
The DAX started at a high of 2,892.57, then pared its gains slightly to trade up 32.52 points at 2,891.12 by 1015 GMT.
Carmaker Volkswagen inched up a few marks after falling nearly five percent on Monday on worries about its legal dispute with General Motors over allegations of industrial espionage.
The dollar and strong bond markets were also behind a strong rally in French shares, which surged nearly 28 points, or 1.2 percent, to around their best levels this year.
"The rise may look excessive but if you look at it objectively, Paris is lagging the other European markets, particularly Frankfurt, where the gap is 500 points," one trader said.
The advance was broadly based, with recent market underperformers leading the move forward. Schneider shares were up 2.04 percent, while LVMH rose 2.4 percent and Michelin was up 2.43 percent.

In London the FTSE 100 index of leading shares was well ahead but off its highs by 1015 GMT. Traders said there were lingering worries about the strength of sterling and a possible rise in interest rates.
"The strength of sterling has been absolutely frightening and it has left the equity market wondering what to do next," said one trader.
CURRENCIES AT 1015 GMT
The dollar was quoted at 1.5653 marks and 114.07 yen against 1.5428 marks and 113.68 yen in late Europe on Monday.
STOCK MARKETS AT 1015 GMT
LONDON - The FTSE 100 index of leading British shares was up 17.7 points, or 0.44 percent, at 4,056.2.
PARIS - The CAC-40 share index was up 27.79 points, or 1.2 percent, at 2,346.42.
FRANKFURT - The 30-share DAX index was up 32.52 points, or 1.14 percent, at 2,891.12.
PRECIOUS METALS
Gold fixed at $369.00 an ounce, down from $370.75 on Monday afternoon and its lowest level since November 2, 1993.
